RECLAMATION OFF TOWN OF SINGAPORE


2.35 p.m.

    The Minister for Law and the Environment (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move the motion* standing in my name as it appears on the Order Paper.
* The motion reads as follows:

    That this Parliament, in accordance with section 4 of the Foreshores Act (chapter 270). approves the reclamation by Government of those portions of the foreshore and seabed off the Town of Singapore containing the respective areas of about 234 hectares and 126 hectares as shown edged in red on the plan marked "LAND OFFICE RECLAMATION PLAN NO 1/77" which is deposited in the Land Office. Singapore.


    Sir, my colleague, the Minister for National Development when announcing Government's decision to proceed with reclamation under Phase VI and VII of the East Coast Reclamation, outlined the development potential which the addition of 360 hectares to our land area will present. The proposals are a seaward extension of existing reclamation works off Tanjong Rhu and Collyer Quay and the additional area to be reclaimed is shown edged in red on the plan marked "LAND OFFICE RECLAMATION PLAN NO. 1/77", a copy of which is displayed in the Library of this House.

    Sir, this reclamation together with the adjoining 218 hectares reclaimed under the earlier Phases will give a total area of 578 hectares or 1441 acres of unencumbered land - large enough to enable the development of a new city for the future. Careful planning and extensive studies will be made to ensure maximum utilization of what can be a valuable piece of real estate. Mr Speaker, Sir, the motion before this House seeks approval under section 4 of the Foreshores Act to carry out this reclamation work.

    The reclamation will be undertaken by the Housing and Development Board as agent of the Government and the fill for the reclamation will be taken from the Tampines worksite of the Housing Board.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to,

PRESIDENT'S SPEECH

Debate on the Address
(Second Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question 114th February, 1977.

    `That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the First Session of this Parliament"', - [Dr Chiang Hai Ding].

    Question again proposed.

2.39 p.m.

    Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, at the close of yesterday's sitting, I was speaking on drug abuses by unscrupulous elements. Their indulgence in such unlawful activities affect the good name of Singapore, and I would now like to continue. The public must be effectively urged and encouraged through the mass media and the cinemas to be vigilant and to give their fullest cooperation in this matter, without which success in the enforcement of severe punishment of offenders will be very minima). There is no doubt that there is a need to extend our sympathy to the innocent who for some reason has been associated with anti-social elements, thus exposing themselves to evil influences. Nevertheless, it is clearly essential to ensure that the penalty fits the crime of drug offences, be they traffickers, pushers or peddlers.

    Sir, the Addendum on the Ministry of National Development in regard to resettlement has prompted me to highlight certain anomalies that need rectification. The rapid development and expansion of public amenities has made resettlement of the people inevitable. Today most of the people have accepted the Government's policy of mass resettlement for national development. However, such a massive movement of people from their familiar surroundings and mode of life as well as their means of livelihood has not been carried out with as little suffering as possible to the people affected. Many affected constituents have

Column: 130

been greatly inconvenienced by unsympathetic bureaucratic Government officers who show little patience and concern to the people affected. The Resettlement Department has not actually taken into consideration the livelihood of the affected elderly farmers, in particular those who have been in this occupation for many years. It is conceivable that they cannot adapt themselves easily to the assembly lines of factories or building sites. It should be the policy of the Resettlement Department to show concern for the livelihood of these people. Admittedly, it is not possible to provide alternative sites for all farmers affected by resettlement. Perhaps the Primary Production Department can assist in alleviating their plight by teaching them the hydroponic method of growing vegetables and fruits, which requires less land.

    Sir, being uprooted from the villages and kampongs is already a great sacrifice for national progress, but to be deprived of their means of livelihood is too high a price for them to pay.

    The monetary compensation awards in lieu of alternative farm sites are not adequate. It is, however, difficult to establish the authenticity of their complaints. Nevertheless, true or false, they are dissatisfied and unhappy. The relevant authorities should look into the matter and rectify any anomaly that may exist, or make every effort to dispel any dissatisfaction in their minds. There seems to be no standard rates of compensation for the loss of fruit trees, pig sties, etc. There are complaints that the affected people are not compensated with the amount originally quoted in writing by the resettlement officers. When discussing resettlement terms, these unsympathetic officers show little patience with the affected people who are illiterate and who are often hurriedly made to sign statements or documents without first being given a clear explanation. They ~re also told in writing to report to the resettlement officers who do not indicate where they should go. When they call at Maxwell Road Office, they are redirected to Toa Payoh Office, without

Column: 131

apology. This happens time and again. They should be specifically told where to go and what to do so that they need not be inconvenienced or waste unnecessary travelling expenses, valuable time and energy.

    Sir, providing them with alternative accommodation at concessional rentals for a certain period will certainly help, but unfortunately these small-time farmers who pay only a few dollars a year for occupying land will definitely find it difficult to pay even the concessionary rent unless in addition they can be given priority of suitable employment. They should be given preference when they apply for a hawker licence. In Changi Village business is practically bad for all the shopkeepers. They are finding it difficult to pay their rent, even though they are given special concessions at the moment. Perhaps the Housing and Development Board can consider deferring the annual increase in their rent until their business improves with the operation of the new Changi International Airport.

    Sir, the Housing and Development Board, on the other hand, must be complimented for its achievement in having completed about a quarter million housing units for 55% of our population. It is most gratifying to note that the HDB is doing a very fine job and will further accelerate the implementation of its fourth five-year Building Programme for another 150,000 units by 1980. This is absolutely encouraging as it reduces the waiting period for applicants wanting to buy or rent HDB flats.

    However, at this pace of development, the quality aspect should not be sacrificed for quantity. More emphasis must be laid on the quality of construction. Presently, there have been numerous complaints from flat owners about the poor finish. Fixtures and fittings are haphazardly completed. This merely proves that there has been a lack of proper and vigilant supervision by HDB which takes over blocks of flats from contractors without first conducting a full inspection of the flats.

    Sir, the problem does not end there. The HDB does not spell out its instructions clearly

Column: 132

to tenants in regard to regulations governing the renovation of flats. Usually after a tenant has completed renovation works, the bureaucratic HDB officers will then come to give a notice to the tenant ordering him to reduce the thickness of the flooring because the thickness of the screed has exceeded the maximum allowed by the Board. But at the time when application for renovation of the flat is made to the Board, the tenant is not informed of certain restrictions. However, when tenants make complaints to the Board about the slipshod work done by the contractors, the HDB officers show no concern at all, except remarking that the defects are minimal. One wonders sometimes why slipshod work on the part of contractors is condoned by the Board.

    Sir, some of the shortcomings of the HDB are causing concern among tenants as well as would-be tenants of H DB accommodation. All these shortcomings should not be thrusted down the throats of the tenants. Nevertheless, we are proud that the HDB's achievement is second to none in other parts of the world.

    An hon. Member: Hear, hear!

    Mr Teo Chong Tee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Addendum on the Ministry of National Development further states the emphasis on planning and improving the social and recreational facilities, better infrastructure and public amenities in pleasant and gracious environment in the next five years. These are positive measures which go along with the building of HDB and HUDC flats. However, we must not forget that the rising cost of leisure is now borne by the general public.

    As for the general public, the Government has established parks, swimming pools and lagoons, zoological gardens and other scenic spots like the Japanese and Chinese gardens and have, at most, levied a small fee far within the reach of the common citizen. The fee is to cover operating costs. There are some other places where no fees are levied at all. These exceptions should not be taken for granted without regard to the funds and effort put into realizing these facilities. Private enterprise establishments which

Column: 133

provide entertainment for the general public, such as the cinemas, have kept their prices within the reach of the general public.

    It is a fact that nothing is for free, and that all needs will have to compete with one another for resources to realise them. Leisure establishments set up by private enterprises are required by their owners to cover costs and eventually make a reasonable return on the capital invested. Citizens who wish to patronise these establishments, such as nightclubs, bowling alleys and golf clubs, must be prepared to pay for these facilities. In order to take a lead in the leisure business, the Government has invested in leisure enterprises such as the Sentosa Golf Club and the Jurong Golf Club - these enterprises are expected to cover not only costs but also to yield a reasonable return on capital invested.

    The takeover of the chalets at Sentosa by a local hotel has invited comments from the general public. According to the plans of the hotel, the area will, be further developed involving a large capital outlay. Members of the public have anticipated that the present high rentals of these chalets will rise even further, beyond the reach of the common Singaporean who wishes to spend his vacation or weekend there.

    Luxurious leisure will always be expensive and exclusive to those who can and wish to pay for them. Simple leisure has yet to be priced out of the reach of the common Singaporean.

    It is true that the proliferation of unlicensed hawkers has been brought under control. Nevertheless, there are still hawkers who for some reason are not being issued with licences, As a result of this, they are constantly harassed by inspectors from the Hawkers Department. These inspectors swoop down on them in the most inhuman way, raiding them like a police party raiding a gangster hideout. Hawkers, young and old, have to leave behind their wares, and sometimes even their money is scattered all over the place, and to run for their lives.

Column: 134

Conveniently, the goods are carted away as if they are contrabands.

    An hon. Member: Shame!

    Mr Teo Chong Tee: Mr Speaker, Sir, these people are not criminals in the true sense of the word. The hawker inspectors are over-zealous in discharging their duties in constituencies where MPs are not Ministers. [Laughter] Indeed it is not a pleasant sight to watch. One just wonders where the seized goods have gone to thereafter, and how are they accounted for and disposed of.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sure my colleagues in this House who face similar problems in their constituencies will fully agree with me that there are shortcomings in the Hawkers Department, which have caused some aberration and defects that need to be improved. The personnel concerned must be educated, particularly in improving their attitude in dealing with the public with respect to their work.

    Sir, I support the Motion in the name of the Member for UIu Pandan.

2.54 p.m.

    Mr Yeo Toon Chia (Ang Mo Kio)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the President in his speech at the opening of this Parliament said that the People's Action Party has once more been returned to power, securing some 72.4% of the votes, the highest ever recorded. With this overwhelming support, the PAP Government has to exercise its power with circumspection and moderation. The President also said that all major policies and legislation will have to be closely scrutinised before implementation. This is quite to the point, and it expresses the desire of the people. In fact, other than some statutory boards, the legislation of most government departments has been brought up to Parliament for scrutiny and debate. But the problem arises after its debate in Parliament when it is put into practice. There will be certain aberrations and inconsistencies in the administrative process, where officers concerned usually shirk their duty, thinking that by doing less fewer mistakes will be

Column: 135

made, and that if they did nothing they would not commit any mistakes at all. So in the end, the voters will get nowhere. They would have wasted their time and money in dealing with the Government departments. Officers in some Government departments are just nonchalant in their attitude and keep themselves away from their post. They make no attempt to try to understand the problems and the needs of the people. Instead they cause the people unnecessary inconvenience. Let me quote some examples. In October last year, the newspapers stated that one, Chou Tieng Shiang, living in a HDB flat was suffering from some chronic illness and could not work and therefore could not pay his rental. He was subsequently evicted by the HDB. When this appeared in the press, members of the public rallied round to help him. When the HDB heard about this, they finally allowed him to return to his flat. The HDB could have been more tolerant and liaised with the Social Welfare Department for help. This illustrates the unsympathetic attitude on the part of the HDB.

    On another occasion, in September last year it was reported in the newspapers that the HDB issued notices to applicants of flats inquiring whether they would be carrying out renovation works to the kitchen and toilet with mosaic. The notice asked for a reply within 10 days failing which their right to apply for the flat would be cancelled. Sir, this is too harsh on them. Many applicants receive the notice late, as the date for a reply stamped on the notice has expired; if not, only a few days left to reply. Moreover, the notice `does not state how much more price they have to pay after such renovation works. In the end, the applicants are confounded over the whole thing and do not know what to do. So they blame the Government.

    Sir, in our meet-the-people sessions in the various constituencies we find a great number of such complaints. The attitude of the HDB in dealing with such cases is really too harsh. It should be rectified and improved. All notices and administrative action formulated by the HDB should be considered by Government leaders before promulgation. We are told that by 1980

Column: 136

about 75% of the population of Singapore, namely two million people, will be housed in HDB flats. They will decide in future which Party should be returned to power, who will form the government. If we do not think about these matters, the consequences may be unsavoury.

    Sir, perhaps we need not dwell too much on the efficiency and ability of Government officers. For instance, in January this year a family in Bukit Merah was hard-pressed financially. The householder, an elderly widow, was a hawker but she was not given a licence to hawk. Being unable to make ends meet, the mother and daughter shut themselves in the flat and burned themselves to death. This very pitiful incident calls for our attention, however rare it may be in our society. When the officers come across cases of extenuating circumstances, they should inquire into them and lend a helping hand in getting them a hawker's licence or liaising with Social Welfare Department. The people concerned should also get in touch with the MP or the CCC in that area so as to avail themselves of better means to help solve their problems. However, it is a pity that out of so many thousands of officers in the various Government departments such as the Hawkers Department, the HDB, and the PUB there was hardly any one who ever tried to come out to study the problems of the unfortunate people and to render help to such people who are in difficulties.

    Sir, it is correct to stress in the Presidential Address that we must get from each his best and give to each according to his performance, since Singapore is a tiny island without any natural resources. Our only resource is manpower in spite of our excellent geographical position and rewarding entrepot trade. Even the footpath is formed by constant trodding. So everything has to depend on our human resources. As we have no other resources, our able political leadership has to mobilise the whole population and consolidate their boundless energy and strength into a concerted effort in nation building and economic progress of our country.

Column: 137



    Sir, Singapore is a new country. Since her foundation, upon which strenuous efforts had been made, education has been spread quite widely and the general level of education of the people is also rising, hopefully to a high standard. But with a short history and a limited economy, we cannot produce a greater number of people with a high level of education. Differences in level of education make for differences in life-style and career expectations, resulting in the fortunate and the unfortunate. The few fortunate people can enjoy the benefits of higher education and reap greater wealth. They are the ones who are better able to give of their best with higher performance, and of course, they get higher rewards. The others, however, those unfortunate ones with poor education and who come from poorer families who have been toiling hard all their lives contributing their best, because of their circumstances and without the benefit of higher education, still cannot reach the higher bracket of reward according to their performance, however hard they exert themselves.

    Sir, so far we have issued hundreds of thousands of work permits to foreign labourers to work in our industries. In the long run, are we sure whether foreign labour will serve our national interest, or will they not bring about more social problems and other burden to us? There is a saying that rather than depend on others, we should depend on our ownselves. For long term social security and in the interest of our nationals, we should look into the reasons why our own citizens do not want to join the labour force. Perhaps we should improve the working conditions of the workers. Why should certain workers be required to work 30 days a month, while others only 24 days? Why can we not allow certain categories of workers to be paid monthly and to let them enjoy the same working conditions as others? There should not be any discrimination in the labour force. Sir, each one of us must contribute our best in order to get the reward according to our worth. We should also try our best for rewards

Column: 138

according to our labour, so that better recognition may be given to the importance of the labourers, who are the less fortunate lot, in our nation building. We should create an amiable environment and better working conditions for all workers so that they may enjoy a better livelihood and the good things in life, so that they can be proud of themselves. We should enable all our nationals who are contributing to the Central Provident Fund to utilise their contributions to buy their own flats and be contented with their lot, so that they could think of themselves as part-owners of Singapore and feel secure and happy living in Singapore. Perhaps, we should go a step further by making a survey of their monthly needs, how much they spend a month on a family of four or five members so as to determine their cost of living. On this basis we should formulate their monthly wages so that they may get the necessary means for their basic livelihood and survival, adapting themselves to the environment and be happy and contented in their career and their lot.

    Finally, on behalf of my constituents, I thank the President for his Address.

3.07 p.m.

    Encik Ahmad Haleem (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the Motion moved by the Member for Ulu Pandan expressing our thanks to the President for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the First Session of this Parliament. The world is currently experiencing an energy crisis and governments are greatly concerned with energy resources and their management. Unfortunately, in Singapore, we have no coal, oil, timber or hydro-electrical energy; therefore, we have to be extremely careful not to waste these increasingly expensive resources. From time to time there have been campaigns over the press, radio and television urging the public to save power and electricity. We should look for as many ways as possible to reduce power consumption, whilst still meeting the needs of our citizens. I believe. Sir, that there

Column: 139

is a way to do this. It is simple and the cost is minimal. I am, Sir, talking about Daylight Saving. This easy-to-implement device could be brought into effect by advancing the clock by one hour at midnight on a chosen day. It will cause the minimum of inconvenience as, apart from advancing the clock by one hour, there will be no other changes in our time schedule. Dawn will then be at six o'clock in the morning instead of at five o'clock and sunset at 7.30 in the evening instead of at 6.30. These are some of the areas where power consumption would be reduced by the introduction of Daylight Saving - in our homes, in public places, sports facilities, lighted advertisements, and in industries running a two-shift system. Side benefits from implementing this scheme are many. Our people, who are being encouraged to take part in all forms of sports and outdoor activities, would have an extra hour of daylight in the evenings, in which to better enjoy the many excellent facilities which are being set up for this purpose. One benefit that I foresee and which, to my mind, is very important is that parents and their children will have an additional hour of daylight in which they can enjoy family games and recreation out of doors, to kick a ball or like one Member of the House told me. "to fly a kite", and so do much to further good parent/child relationship.

    Internationally, our advancing the clock by one hour should be just a minor adjustment for our trading partners to make. With the introduction of Daylight Saving, all school fields could be opened up after school, and football fields and all the games courts would be better used. Even if these spaces were made available to our people they would still be insufficient to meet our needs. I, therefore, welcome the Sports Council Master Plan for the building of squash and tennis courts, swimming pools, football pitches, fitness parks and the multi-purpose indoor stadia. Unfortunately, I feel that the Master Plan, for the most part, caters for the "have's" and neglects the "have-not's". You will notice most of the facilities are revenue-generating. This immediately eliminates our younger citizens who cannot pay but whose needs for

Column: 140

open fields and games courts should be recognised. They need more facilities where team games can be played, spontaneously, and where easy mixing and integration of our people will be encouraged. I disagree with the Sports Council's rationale in their Sports for All policy where the emphasis is on mass participation and they do not feel the need to aim at producing champions.

    It is human nature that the presence of a champion leader encourages others to follow. The case of badminton is a good example of this. In the 50's when the standard of our players then taking part in the Thomas Cup and the All England Championship was very high, badminton was extremely popular. The popularity of badminton has greatly waned, now that we are no longer producing champions. In the same way, if we wish to popularise other sports and get more participants, we must also produce champions in all fields. Every schoolboy wants to be a Pele or a Mark Spitz. Our constituency games also are not popular. For many constituencies the reasons they are unable to produce good teams are lack of money and facilities. I am not advocating paying participants to take part in sports. Far from it. I am entirely against this policy, but in order to produce a good side it is necessary to hold regular intra-constituency tournaments and to arrange many practice sessions. All these require facilities and money. It is unfair and undesirable for the constituency to go around asking their constituents for frequent donations. Therefore, I suggest that the constituency sports rules be amended to allow for sponsorship by business firms. Of course, when a company sponsors the sports in the constituency, they would like to see a return for their money. We should allow players to use the firm's logos on their jerseys. In this way, both parties will benefit. I would still expect the grant from the Sports Council to continue. because every cent that can be gathered will help immensely towards the promotion of sports. I should also like to see our champions and gold medal winners who represent Singapore and bring honour to our country, rewarded by giving them priority

Column: 141

allocation for housing. Anyone who knows and sees the long hours of practice a winner must put in, will not begrudge him this privilege.

    The Housing and Development Board should build more sports facilities in their estates. When the Government was first considering how to tackle the problem of' resettling large numbers of our citizens, their primary concern, and rightly so, was to build housing units as fast as possible. We have now reached a stage where quantity alone is not sufficient to meet the total needs of our people. Their physical needs are well catered for in spacious and sanitary housing, shops and markets, clinics and other services. Now is the time to consider how best to meet their emotional needs to bring about a healthy sense of integration in their new environment, Open spaces in the estates should be converted into children's playgrounds, games and family recreation areas. It is insufficient to provide new parks in selected areas because parents would much prefer their children to play nearer their homes, to kick a ball around, scream and shout and allow healthy daily outlets for their natural drives. If immediate provision is not found for expressing these drives, they will be suppressed, and we will be facing a generation of maladjusted young citizens in the near future. Drug problems and other unhealthy manifestations of this repression will most certainly increase by leaps and bounds. I speak not only in my new role as a Backbencher and educationist but as a parent as well. The subject I shall speak on will concern all parents, that is, Education,

    It is, I believe, the responsibility of the Government to provide the right kind of education for our children, as the right kind of education is the key to a good life, a good conduct, a correct attitude, a key to the world, both our own and the bigger one outside. Education being a process of living and an inseparable part of one's personal development, as one journeys through life's maze of problems and pressures, its importance cannot be over-stressed. This, I think, is recognized. However, while we have all recognized its importance and implications, have we been mapping out and implementing the right policies in education? It is a difficult task, rio doubt. And upon the shoulders of the Ministry of Education has fallen this difficult task. The Ministry of Education is not only responsible for the formulation of our present educational policies, it should also be responsible for their successful implementation and to ensure their practicality and usefulness. Has this been the case? This is the question.

    The past few years have seen a great deal of debate on and discussion of our education system, not only within this House but also without. In some cases, the deliberations have been very intense, mainly in the problem areas. Much has also been printed on the subject. One particular newspaper published a series of articles, based on surveys it conducted. Parents and teachers joined in the fray with their letters and articles in the Mentor, the official organ of the Singapore Teachers' Union. Much of the statements has been critical. Some of the utterances have been evaluative and useful. There have also been instances of angry and contemptuous comment. All these go to show the immense concern our people in general have over the education of their children, in the future of their children. The questions that follow are: How much have we who are in Government taken note of all

Column: 182

these? How much of the useful points raised have we used in our reviews and reevaluation of policies? There appears to be a continuing discontent over our educational policies.

    Sir, let me touch upon a few areas in our educational policies and our education system which have brought about a great deal of unhappiness and not a little confusion. The unhappiness and confusion apparently cut across the entire score board - principals, teachers, parents and pupils. The general feeling during the past few years has been that students have been made the "guinea-pigs" of what appeared to be a series of rather haphazard experiments formulated totally on an ad hoc basis, without any prior research nor any in-depth study done. Principals and teachers are equally apprehensive and concerned over the frequent "chops and changes". But most concerned of all are parents, naturally. They are often heard complaining about the frequent implementation of short-lived policies and new ideas, only to be aborted before they have time to take root. New experiments are abandoned as swiftly as they are implemented. Can we wonder the concern expressed all around? The recent Ministry of Education announcement of its decision to impose a second language requirement for entry into pre-university classes in 1979 and 1980 is an example of what has generated much concern among parents. It has also aroused anger and annoyance. Students begin to feel insecure all over again, unsure of their future and what is actually to come.

    What is needed now is to convince all concerned, especially parents whose children are, in the final analysis, the ones to benefit or to suffer, that there is every justification for this fresh imposition. There may be, as there should be, very good grounds for the move. But if there are, we have not heard them in clear terms, in simple language, and in convincing tone. What parents and pupils are uneasy about is that this may yet be another one of those many new experiments and new ideas that crop up in the minds of Ministry officials. What they wish to know is whether

this new decision is the result of a careful study and survey of the real needs of pre-university students. And would this really create a new thirst for the learning of a second or third language? We must presume that the situation has been fully assessed and evaluated. But has it? Factual and forthright answers to these various questions would go a long way to dispel the doubts lingering in the minds of parents and pupils. I think we need these answers and assurances.

Sir, as far as I know, when the Education For Living idea was introduced, it was aimed to give exposure to pupils doing a second language, which may not necessarily be the mother tongue. Let me give an example. To many children who go to an English-medium school, English is a foreign language. schools, where all kinds of what must have appeared to parents and pupils alike, very ad hoc ideas and decisions - like the Primary Pilot Project, the Education For Living, and what have you! While the number of these new-fangled ideas introduced in the recent years has been disconcerting, the frequency with which they have been introduced has been astounding. Where have all these ideas so suddenly come from? The answer would be enlightening.

It would be unrealistic, and it would be impractical.

I feel that there should be a spiritual balance too in our education system. This would certainly combat the making of future drug addicts, drug traffickers, gangsters and other such like men of menace in society. A touch of religion is always good. Any moral value, strengthened by religious belief, at once becomes a matter of greater conviction and a better sense. Otherwise, the trend towards a money-minded and materialistic society

Column: 185

would continue unabated. Proper, correct all round education should provide for the development of the intellectual, physical, social, aesthetic, and spiritual, areas of a growing person. One need not be a fanatic in any of these areas. A balance of all these aspects of the growing process is most desirable. This should be our aim and purpose in teaching the young.

    As a last point, may I now turn my attention to the area of Extra-Curricular Activities, or ECA for short. The aims and objectives are laudable enough. We do want the rugged Singaporean more than just bookworms, As they say, a sound mind in a sound body is the best thing in the world. Games are made for health. Debates and the like are made for intelligent enjoyment. Uniformed organisations are made for smartness and discipline. Other ,extracurricular activities are made for leisure. These are all fine, until their implementation goes wrong, until the importance becomes lopsided, until the real purpose goes cockeyed. The over-stress placed on ECA activities in the recent years has turned the original aim and purpose more than a little awry. The result? Pupils participate in ECA activities not so much to better themselves physically or to better the correct enjoyment of their leisure, but to gain points to add to their academic achievements, in order to gain admission to pre.-university classes. This is true in countless instances in schools all over the island. All this again has been the result of over-emphasis placed on a "new idea" - I say "new idea" because the idea of physical well-being complementing mental and intellectual well-being is as old as the hills.

    Sir, my purpose in bringing up all these various points is not so much to be unduly critical, but merely to express the general feeling prevalent among principals, teachers, parents and pupils like. But more importantly, to urge the authorities concerned to make a careful and an in-depth study - a real, genuine survey - of a situation before making policy changes which in the ultimate analysis affect our

Column: 186

citizens as a whole, for today's school children are tomorrow's citizens of the State, who will have a hand in the running of the government, the business world and society. The implications of a drastic change is often lost sight of in the enthusiasm of implementing a new idea. The frequency of changes can also be bewildering. But these would be quite in order if they are made after a careful study, not just because a few principals happen to agree with the changes. I do not think I need elaborate on the importance of a good survey and the value of a thorough study before one embarks upon a new idea which is to be implemented and which will affect the lives of hundreds of thousands of our future citizens.

Otherwise the unhealthy feeling of "throat-ramming" will, rightly or wrongly, persist. Needless to say, a policy change in .education that has the acceptance and support of the people - parents in particular - is certainly bound to have a greater chance of success than otherwise. Any successful policy change is also bound to be easier to maintain and sustain upon implementation, thereby avoiding the rather unpleasant task of having to make frequent "chops and changes" and to offer repeated explanations.
